headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: A.I. and the Future of Humanity. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The implications come to the forefront. You see in some cases A.I. bumbling along.

utterances.speaker: NICK WATT, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Listen, we've got an election next. That could be totally compromised. We have to think about the here and now. It's not just "Terminator" in the future, it's now, Jim. It's now.

utterances.speaker: ACOSTA
utterances.sentences: All right.And speaking of now, your special is coming up just about now. Nick Watt, thank you so much. "A.I. AND THE FUTURE OF HUMANITY" is next right here on CNN. Make sure you watch that. Thank you very much for joining me this evening. Reporting from Washington, I'm Jim Acosta. I'll see you next weekend. Good night.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.Artificial intelligence or A.I. is an incredibly powerful technology which may change many aspects of our lives. The CEO of Google's parent company, Alphabet, which has invested heavily in it, recently said A.I.'s impact could be more profound than electricity or even fire. But many worry about what that impact might turn out to be. A.I. COOPER: Could A.I. one day replace humans? And if so, how might that happen? We've already seen some service-based and manufacturing jobs turn to A.I. in a big way. But what about other industries? Can A.I. replace journalists or news anchors? Perhaps it already has.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Because what you just saw and heard a moment ago was not actually me. This is me, Anderson Cooper.A.I. COOPER: And I am an A.I.-generated Anderson Cooper.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: That wasn't my real voice, and I never spoke the words you just heard. We asked a young student in California to create a fully end-to-end A.I. version of me. Looks like me, sounds like me, and it didn't take him very long to do it. A.I. COOPERactually with open-source tools. And remember this technology is still in its infancy. It's only going to get better, and faster and more accurate, which raises all sorts of questions, like how will we know what's real --

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: And what is not? Not just when it comes to believing what you see on TV but everything from creating art, fighting wars, even waging political campaigns.Over the next hour, CNN's Nick Watt brings us inside the race to develop A.I. and the attempts to contain it. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) A.I. VOICE: Looking for a good spot to pull over.

utterances.speaker: NICK WATT, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: You think this is our car?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: OK. I guess the first test is whether it runs me over. Start ride. So that's the view I'm getting from the back seat, that wheel moving with no hands.Look, mom, no hands. This is freaky. (Voice-over): This robot taxi already roaming the streets of San Francisco gives us a very good idea of where we are. Pretty cool if you can get past the weird empty driver's seat. (Voice-over): And where we might be going. Many A.I. algorithms already behave, well, kind of human. In California, obviously, you can turn right on red, and it's trying to turn right. It's going to do it. Go on, mate. Go on. Nice. (Voice-over): The flesh and blood driver that used to sit here is already obsolete. This is our future. Humans sitting in the backseat doing nothing. (Voice-over): Some humans are scared, some trying hard to stop it. For now, humans are still in control of A.I. and this cab, there's a human supervisor in a call center. Can you tell that he's not wearing his seatbelt properly?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, correct.WATT (voice-over): But for how long? That's where much of A.I. is at the moment, imperfect and speeding ahead without a seatbelt. Like it or not, this is our future. A higher being is driving the car. (Voice-over): For hundreds of thousands of years, humans have been the most intelligent beings on this earth. Not for much longer. We're creating tech that will take us well beyond self-driving cars, tech that will outsmart us all. Will A.I. save us, or will A.I. kill us?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: (INAUDIBLE) worldwide is one of the leading experts in artificial intelligence, please welcome to the stage, Yoshua Bengio.(APPLAUSE)

utterances.speaker: YOSHUA BENGIO, SCIENTIFIC DIRECTOR, MONTREAL INSTITUTE FOR LEARNING ALGORITHMS
utterances.sentences: Governments need to protect all of us with technology, which could be amazingly useful and also risky.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Yoshua Bengio is a deep learning pioneer. That's basically teaching computers to behave like human brains.

utterances.speaker: BENGIO
utterances.sentences: The stuff that you'd find in ChatGPT, many of its major ingredients came from Mila.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Mila, the Montreal Institute for Learning Algorithms, founded by Bengio in the '90s in a building that was once a clothing factory. Now they produce ideas, algorithms already changing humanity.There are going to be machines that are way smarter than you.

utterances.speaker: BENGIO
utterances.sentences: If we choose so and we don't destroy civilization before that, we could get there, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: What is the biggest fear? It's humans using this technology or humans losing control of this technology?

utterances.speaker: BENGIO
utterances.sentences: They're both valid fears. For the foreseeable future, it's going to be humans doing bad things with powerful technology like they have done in the past. But now very more powerful technology. It's also conceivable that at some point we could lose control, and that's potentially even worse.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: If you're scared, why don't you just shut up shop and go become a farmer? Your research could be contributing to the end of all of us.

utterances.speaker: BENGIO
utterances.sentences: I'm asking that question myself every morning.Rich enough state's base essentially. I wonder if there's a way to do like maybe change the perspective. Why I'm continuing right now is in part because I think that it is possible to build A.I. systems that would be totally safe and incredibly useful. WATT (voice-over): But if A.I. does go rogue "Terminator" style, we'd lose control or more likely we'd just program it badly, there could be unintended but indelible consequences. STUART RUSSELL, FOUNDER, CENTER FOR HUMAN-COMPATIBLE A.I. AT UC BERKELEY: Let's make sure that we fix climate change. If that's the objective that the machine has, fix climate change, OK, well, I guess who's causing the climate change? Humans. OK. Easiest way, end the human race, right?

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Stuart Russell is another godfather of artificial intelligence. He literally wrote the textbook on A.I.

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL
utterances.sentences: My first A.I. program I wrote in high school, which is about 48 years ago.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Forty-eight years later, most A.I. systems can do single things better than us. Recognize a face, play chess.

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL
utterances.sentences: What we're aiming towards in A.I. is general purpose A.I., meaning A.I. systems that can do anything that human beings can do.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: One system that can learn, even teach itself to do anything, everything better than us.A.I., I would say, probably definitely is going to just completely upend our entire sort of economic structure and how we've seen things for centuries, if not millennia.

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL
utterances.sentences: Yes.WATT (voice-over): At Berkeley, Russell leads a small army of researchers. At the Center for Human Compatible Artificial Intelligence.

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL
utterances.sentences: Given that it's going to be more powerful than human beings, how do you ensure that humans have power over it forever?

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: And?

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL
utterances.sentences: Right? That's the question that we're working on.WATT (voice-over): Russell and many other tech leaders called in March for a global pause on deploying advanced A.I. systems while we figure out the guardrails. There has been no such pause. The problem is right now it's people like you, who are soft-spoken intellectuals making this point and signing these letters.

utterances.speaker: RUSSELL
utterances.sentences: Yes, it doesn't seem like a fair fight. But I would say the tenor of discussion has changed radically. People are listening. Even Sam Altman, the CEO of OpenAI, which produces ChatGPT and all these systems, has called for regulation.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.sentences: Let me be clear. This executive order represents bold action, but we still need Congress to act.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: You're optimistic.ALEX WANG, CEO AND CO-FOUNDER, SCALE A.I.: I'm optimistic. WATT (voice-over): Just across the bay from Berkeley, in downtown San Francisco, I met 26-year-old Alex Wang, one of the tech leaders fueling the A.I. arms race.

utterances.speaker: WANG
utterances.sentences: I started the company when I was 19.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: That takes some balls.

utterances.speaker: WANG
utterances.sentences: What went through my head is the technology is going to move so fast, that I'm going to really regret it if I --

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: WANG
utterances.sentences: If I don't get involved.WATT (voice-over): He is co-founder and CEO of Scale A.I. His big idea, to provide A.I. developers with the one thing they all need, massive amounts of data organized. In 2022, "Forbes" dubbed him the youngest self-made billionaire in the world. He's now working with the Department of Defense. Around Washington, he's known as an A.I. whisperer.

utterances.speaker: WANG
utterances.sentences: We want to be sure to not overregulate the technology because if we accidentally overregulate, we could, you know -- we could damage or hurt decades and decades of economic progress and decades and decades of innovation.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: I don't know you. You seem like a nice person. But it's people like you who are young, who are wealthy, who are set to make a lot more money from this tech. Why should we believe that you really are in this for all of us at this crucial moment for our species?

utterances.speaker: WANG
utterances.sentences: Well, ultimately I think this is one of the reasons why working with the U.S. government is actually so critical, because, you know, our government has a number of mechanisms and checks and balances and procedures, and it was designed to ensure that the government ultimately reflects the will and the desires of the people.One of the things that I'm most concerned about are bad actors utilizing artificial intelligence to, you know, ultimately exert their will globally, authoritarianism versus democracy. You know, we have a number of countries, China and Russia, investing aggressively into using artificial intelligence to further their aims.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Five or 10 years from now, how different is our world going to look because of A.I., in terms of our everyday lives and in terms of the geopolitical structure of our planet?

utterances.speaker: WANG
utterances.sentences: I think the quote goes, you know, we always overestimate what will happen in one year but underestimate what will happen in 10 years. When it gets really embedded into every way, every function of humanity, everything that happens, I think it will be quite shocking and amazing what the world will look like.WATT (voice-over): You might be asking, so what will my world look like? Well, stay tuned, and we'll show you. GERT-JAN OSKAM, ABLE TO WALK WITH THE HELP OF A.I.: That's something that wasn't possible before.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Do you ever wonder that you're in danger of sort of losing touch with what's real and what's not?

utterances.speaker: HANY FARID, PROFESSOR, UC BERKELEY SCHOOL OF INFORMATION
utterances.sentences: You're quickly entering this time where anything you see, read, or hear online can be fake. And what does that mean? Nothing is real anymore, right? This interview isn't real. I'm not real. You're not real.WATT (voice-over): Hany Farid really is a Berkeley professor. His main focus, misinformation.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: We can deny reality. A politician getting caught saying something inappropriate on a hot mic, it's fake. You don't have to cop to it.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Where does that leave us as --

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: Yes, as a society, as a democracy. Like if we can --

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: As a human being?

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: Yes. I don't know. How do you have a democracy if we can't trust the basic facts of what's happening in the world?A.I. GENERATED FAKE VIDEO OF VICE PRESIDENT KAMALA HARRIS: Today is today, and yesterday was today yesterday. FARID: You revert back to tribalism. This is my people. I trust them. Listen to what do my tribe say, right? And that is dangerous.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: We're on the precipice of an election.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: Oh, (EXPLETIVE DELETED) me. You're already seeing deep fakes entering into elections.A.I. GENERATED FAKE VIDEO OF GOVERNOR RON DESANTIS: I've realized I need to drop out of this race immediately.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Officials closed the city of San Francisco this morning.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: There are people, by the way, who will say, well, we don't really think that can change an election. And then I will remind people that in the last two elections, national elections, the difference between one candidate and the other can be measured in tens of thousands of votes. I know exactly what town to go into and what state and what persona to go after, and I can carpet bomb them with misinformation all day long. I move 80,000 votes, that's the ball game. Right?

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: So what do we do? I mean, you're the man I'm pinning my hopes on to save us.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: There are some things we can do, but they're hard. OK. We build what are called behavioral models, and then when a video is released of President Biden, track the head, track the upper body, track the voice, and then we just compare them. Is this behaviorally the same as what we have seen?WATT (voice-over): Takes time, and the damage might already have been done.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: A fake image of a Pentagon bombing was uploaded to Twitter on a verified account that looked like Bloomberg News, and in two minutes, the stock market dropped a half a trillion dollars from a single fake image. So we're in the detection business, understand. We're in the business of trying to defend against this harmful content. But to do that, you have to understand what is possible.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Enter Farid's protege, Matty (INAUDIBLE), 18 years old, fresh from his native Czech Republic. His fascination with A.I. brought him here to California. He convinced Professor Fareed to take him on.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: That's so sweet.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: He's a tech guy. He's supposed to look kind of rumpled.(Voice-over): Matty, with his mentor's guidance, made that Anderson Cooper deepfake you watched a few minutes ago.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We used one of the online tools that's out there. We basically trained a model to synthesize voice in particular Anderson Cooper's style. And then we just give it a text, and in a couple of seconds, we had the perfect audio.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: And you just graduated high school.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's right, three weeks ago.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: You're too young, but you might -- you know, when like the news anchor was the voice of God and you believed in everything that that anchor said.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: And now any high school kid, no offense, can put words into that anchor's mouth.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: Let alone a president or a CEO or you or me. I think in China, they're using completely -- I just sent you the article.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: FARID
utterances.sentences: Completely virtual newscasters now.

utterances.speaker: ENGLISH ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: I'm an English artificial intelligence anchor.WATT (voice-over): If an 18-year-old can do this, imagine what a big- time Hollywood player can do with A.I. SCOTT MANN, CO-CEO AND FOUNDER, FLAWLESS: What you're looking at here, I think, is the studio of the future. It's how we make movies. How we go about doing it is changing.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: What's it going to mean to me sitting on my La-Z-Boy.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You and my (EXPLETIVE DELETED) car.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Gretch, no, you mother (EXPLETIVE DELETED).

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Reshooting the movie without the swearing would have cost lots of time and money. They didn't have to. Thanks to A.I., this --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Now we're stuck on this stupid (EXPLETIVE DELETED) tower in the middle of (EXPLETIVE DELETED) nowhere.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Became this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Now we're stuck on this stupid freaking tower in the middle of freaking nowhere.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: That tech developed by Flawless A.I. founded by Mann and a tech biz insider Nick Lines in 2018.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: We can take new dialogue spoken by this actress, by Ginnie, and because the system understands how she speaks, we're able to create new mouth articulations for that line.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Remember, Hollywood went on strike in part over fears A.I. algorithms would steal actors' images and performances. Mann is not doing that. The actors are involved. They voice the new lines. They just don't all have to go out and reshoot to get rid of a cuss word or fix a flaw.I mean, you are not a tech guy. You are not a business guy.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: ROBERT DE NIRO, ACTOR
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. Maybe I just have a stroke on my way over here.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: I've done a film called "Heist," and then I saw a foreign dub of that movie. And that's when I realized films are being ruined every time they are dubbed, and it kind of set me off on a bit of an adventure to try and figure a way to fix it. So over here the guys are working on a movie called "UFO Sweden." This is a movie that was shot, an incredible movie that's in Swedish.WATT (voice-over): Thanks to this new tech, Mann will release the original "UFO Sweden" but in English.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You're one black mark away from youth custody, and you want to hang out with those idiots again?

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: I want to get on to talking about what you do in a second, but while we're on this bigger picture, there's one other thing I want to ask you.(Through text translation): If I wanted to speak perfect Spanish at this moment, do you really think you would be able to do it?

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: But we are at the stage or we will soon be at the stage where actually the entire creative process is taken over by A.I.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: I would say no. The really good movies typically tap into some kind of human exploration. It's born from feeling, and you're delivering feeling. And the one thing A.I. can't do is feel. It's not human at the end of the day. So --

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: It can be trained to feel like us.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: No, it can be trained to emulate us. You know, the best human instinct you could say is survival. I think a lesson A.I. has feelings that relate into that notion, I don't think that it's ever going to be like us.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: It clearly has tapped into a primal fear in us as humans. It's basically tapped into our survival instinct.

utterances.speaker: MANN
utterances.sentences: Yes, rightly so. There's enormous good that can come out of this done right.WATT (voice-over): Next --

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: We came to Lausanne, Switzerland, on the very Bonnie Banks of Lake Geneva to dive into some A.I. optimism. To meet two medical pioneers.You should go and save someone's life.

utterances.speaker: JOCELYNE BLOCH, NEUROSURGEON, LAUSANNE UNIVERSITY HOSPITAL
utterances.sentences: Yes. OK. So I'm going.WATT (voice-over): She was sidetracked by emergency brain surgery. We'll get back to them both in a minute. We were also sidetracked in Lausanne, also by something potentially lifesaving. Far from the old town in a building that looks like a school gymnasium, we found this.

utterances.speaker: YVES MARTIN, DEPUTY DIRECTOR, SWISS PLASMA CENTER
utterances.sentences: It's a tokamak.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: A tokamak.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: Tokamak.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Tokamak. OK.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: Yes.WATT (voice-over): It's been around since the Soviets had an idea in the 1950s, but no human on earth has managed to make a tokamak really work. But these physicists are partnered with Google DeepMind, one of the most advanced A.I. labs in the world, and now think that they can finally crack it.

utterances.speaker: MARTIN
utterances.sentences: The idea is to reproduce the sound on earth to reproduce energy.

utterances.speaker: OLIVIER SAUTER, SENIOR SCIENTIST, SWISS PLASMA CENTER
utterances.sentences: With A.I., there's a chance to do it within 10, 20 years.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: To heat plasma to 150 million degrees Celsius, to initiate nuclear fusion, to create near endless clean, cheap, and safe power. There's the plasma. Magnets must stop it touching the sides of the container. The magnets need constant tweaking.

utterances.speaker: ANTOINE MERLE, RESEARCH SCIENTIST, SWISS PLASMA CENTER
utterances.sentences: Humans cannot do it in real time. Everything is happening so fast.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: But the A.I. can?

utterances.speaker: BENGIO
utterances.sentences: Let's see. Health and environment. It could be that in 20 years we've cured pretty much all diseases. I'm not saying it's happening, it's going to happen, but there's that kind of potential.WATT (voice-over): So back to those suave medical pioneers and their seemingly impossible dream.

utterances.speaker: GREGOIRE COURTINE, PROFESSOR, SWISS FEDERAL INSTITUTE OF TECHNOLOGY, LAUSANNE
utterances.sentences: To have someone come into this hospital paralyzed and walking out of this hospital normal.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: So explain to me who does what here. You're the surgeon.

utterances.speaker: BLOCH
utterances.sentences: I'm the surgeon.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: And I'm the neuroscientist.WATT (voice-over): And Gert-Jan Oskam is a laconic determined Dutchman, paralyzed in a bicycle accident in China more than a decade ago. In me, my thoughts transfer down my spine, and that makes me walk. But with you, that connection was broken, is that right?

utterances.speaker: OSKAM
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Do you remember what happened?

utterances.speaker: OSKAM
utterances.sentences: No, nothing. No.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: You were on your bicycle and then the next thing --

utterances.speaker: OSKAM
utterances.sentences: The day they found me on the streets, the police picked me up, brought me in the hospital. And when I woke up, I didn't feel my legs anymore. So the doctor told me like I could touch my face with my left or right hand, and he said like be happy with this. It won't get better.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: And how do you deal with that as a person?

utterances.speaker: OSKAM
utterances.sentences: I always said to my family that I would walk again. I told them one year, but it apparently needed 10 years.WATT (voice-over): Ten years for A.I. to catch up with the dream. Tech that began many years ago as a sci-fi sketch drawn on a napkin in a New York steakhouse. COURTINE: When I draw a brain and a spinal cord, and there was a digital bridge to restart working after paralysis.

utterances.speaker: BLOCH
utterances.sentences: But at this time it was a dream.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Were you imagining this reading the thoughts?

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: Yes. I thought it was crazy.WATT (voice-over): Now reality. A paralyzed man is up and about.

utterances.speaker: BLOCH
utterances.sentences: So we are doing two surgeries. The classical one is on the spinal cord. So where we would put electrodes above the spinal cord, the region of the spinal cord that is controlling that movement, and this other surgery that is quite novel, is the one above the brain. This implant is going to work wirelessly and activate the spinal cord stimulation.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: A.I., for us, has become a friend for the past 10 years. You know, this is a research partner that is no part of the laboratory activities, and without which we could not operate.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: You could not operate?

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: When you're facing sometime huge amount of data, which us human being are not able to understanding what's happening, machine learning can tell us.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: The A.I. can detect how much the person wants to make a movement, not just the movement.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: That is correct. Gert-Jan just have to think about it. So we're turning thought into action.

utterances.speaker: OSKAM
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's something that was impossible before.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: So now we turn on the system, and you can see that Gert-Jan can actually step. And we're going to turn it off. Now it's off, and you see that he's frozen. Now it's very difficult for him. He's trying.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: Back on, and he can perform some steps again.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: But that's -- I mean, I'm kind of surprised that you can have a conversation with me, and this is still picking up when you want to move your legs.

utterances.speaker: OSKAM
utterances.sentences: Yes. It can really discriminate brain signals.

utterances.speaker: WATT
utterances.sentences: Yes.When was the moment that you realized that it worked? COURTINE: It was sad for me because this one day, I was not present.

utterances.speaker: BLOCH
utterances.sentences: He was not present because he did not realize that it would be so fast.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: But she doesn't tell you that everybody was crying in the room.WATT (voice-over): Gert-Jan doesn't walk the way he did before his accident, not yet. Maybe never. But with every A.I.-aided step, he's getting stronger. His body is actually repairing itself.

utterances.speaker: COURTINE
utterances.sentences: When using this system for a long period of time for training, nerve fibers start growing again. So we repair the nervous system with this technology.

utterances.speaker: WATT
